problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: In the balanced reaction \(\ce{2H2 + O2 -> 2H2O}\), how many moles of water are produced from 3 moles of \(\ce{H2}\) (assuming excess \(\ce{O2}\))?
problems.detailed: The reaction ratio between \(\ce{H2}\) and \(\ce{H2O}\) is 2:2, so 3 moles of \(\ce{H2}\) will produce 3 moles of \(\ce{H2O}\) × (2/2) = 3 moles. Actually wait—because the coefficient for \(\ce{H2O}\) is 2 for 2 \(\ce{H2}\), the ratio is 1:1, so 3 moles \(\ce{H2}\) gives 3 moles water..

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: If 5 grams of \(\ce{Na}\) react with excess \(\ce{Cl2}\) by \(\ce{2Na + Cl2 -> 2NaCl}\), which substance runs out first?
problems.detailed: Molar mass of \(\ce{Na}\) ~23 g/mol, so 5 g is ~0.217 mol. For that, need half as many moles of \(\ce{Cl2}\) to react fully. If we assume "excess \(\ce{Cl2}\)", \(\ce{Na}\) is limiting, so \(\ce{Na}\) runs out first.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: In the equation \(\ce{C + O2 -> CO2}\), if you start with 12 g of carbon, how many grams of \(\ce{CO2}\) can theoretically be produced? (Molar masses: C = 12 g/mol, O = 16 g/mol)
problems.hint: Find moles of C then use reaction stoichiometry.
problems.detailed: 12 g C = 1 mol. By reaction, that forms 1 mol \(\ce{CO2}\). Molar mass of \(\ce{CO2}\) = 12 + 2×16 = 44 g. So 44 g \(\ce{CO2}\).

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Which of the following defines a limiting reactant in a chemical reaction?
options: The reactant present in largest mass
The reactant which is entirely consumed first
The reactant that does not react at all
The reactant that forms the most product
problems.hint: Limiting = stops the reaction from making more product.
problems.detailed: A limiting reactant is the one that is completely used up first, and thus limits how much product can form.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: If the reaction \(\ce{2Fe + 3Cl2 -> 2FeCl3}\) is carried out with 4 moles of \(\ce{Fe}\) and 5 moles of \(\ce{Cl2}\), which is in excess?
problems.hint: Use stoichiometric ratios to compare required amounts.
problems.detailed: The stoichiometric ratio needs 3 moles \(\ce{Cl2}\) for every 2 moles \(\ce{Fe}\). For 4 moles \(\ce{Fe}\), need 6 moles \(\ce{Cl2}\), but only have 5 moles. So \(\ce{Cl2}\) is limiting, therefore \(\ce{Fe}\) is in excess.
